column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$2$3$Doctor in hospital diagnosed me with Schizophrenia
column3: but my doctor has said he is prescribing it for Bipolar...and put me on 15mg to start...I read where this might be prescribed at higher doses for Bipolar and lower doses for Schizophrenia...at 15mg I was gaining about 1-2 pounds per month
column4: but at the same time was actively walking outside every day...I got so that I became very dizzy and had an abrupt feeling of faint at times...I spoke to my medication prescriber's office about the dizziness and abrupt feeling of faint and to see if lowering my dose would help...went to my MD at their request to be cleared for medical reasons in order to do this and found out my blood pressure was above borderline and he wanted to put me on Lisinopril... I read online that Abilify can cause High Blood pressure or Fluctuating blood pressure...my prescriber's office still would not lower my dose...I felt this med was doing more harm than good...I then went to see a neurologist...I was told this medication can cause the dizziness and went back to my prescriber...reluctantly my dose was lowered by 5 mg...the abrupt feeling of faint has not returned by I do still get a feeling of vertigo or dizzy at times...my blood pressure went to borderline...I was told at some point if I could drop some weight this might help...I've been working out in a gym on a treadmill and lifting weights for over a year...the most weight I lost was 10 pounds...I am trying dieting now...I feel I need to ask for my dosage to be lowered again to see if my blood pressure will drop...read online in NY Times article on young adults taking Abilfy...that lowering the dose does not help with weight loss...I will continue to diet and exercise even still...and see about getting the dose to see if my blood pressure will go down...

19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$4$5$"Although I feel that Zyprexa is the most efficacious anti-psychotic on the market (it just has very serious side effects
column3: such as diabetes related to weight gain)
column4: in my opinion
column5: Abilify is (perhaps surprisingly) a close second.  Abilify has very minimal side effects (unlike most of the other anti-psychotics); however
column6: it didn't completely quell my symptoms - I still experienced some psychotic feelings.  This is not surprising
column8: because Abilify is the newest (and ""weakest"") anti-psychotic.  By ""weakest"" I am referring to the fact that it is only a partial dopamine agonist
column11: facilitates the manifestation of some psychotic symptoms.  However
column13: Abilify is a highly efficacious drug.  For me
column15: it just wasn't quite strong enough
column16: so I switched to Zyprexa (which quells my psychotic symptoms
column17: but has its own related side effects *see my Zyprexa posting*).  In sum
column18: Abilify is a very gentle drug that is well tolerated by many people.  Given the potential side effects of other anti-psychotic drugs
column19: I would try Abilify as my first line of defense.  Who knows?  It just might work.   "
